ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: greater appreciation of how value systems drive architectural design and the utilization of biomaterials for a more sustainable future; thought-provoking innovations on the biomaterial front; great guest lectures and super interesting readings :)
Biobased material lifecycles as they relate to architecture and construction, historical, contemporary, and future.
The use of biodegradable materials and how to use adobe indesign
The impacts of a set of biobased materials in terms of carbon footprints and the environment in general

I learned about how different agricultural products, such as bamboo, mycelium, timber and other items, can be used in construction. We went in depth on the life cycles and embodied energies of all the processes involved. There was a big focus on sustainability, resourcefulness, and applicability.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: a super short crash course on the design softwares that architects / architecture papers use would be super helpful
Seminar size but lecture-only format. Could be a strength or a weakness depending on who you are. Great guest lectures!

The professor encourages all comments during discussion. 
The guest lectures are often through zoom, and not the most engaging way of having lectures. Also, the lectures are a little long, and I would prefer that they are broken up into different days.

SUPER interesting topics. Mae Ling is incredibly knowledgeable about the topic and is a major voice in her field, learning from her was amazing. The readings gave useful context but weren't always necessary. The lessons were a bit too relaxed of a pace, it was hard to focus for long. I would split up the class to meet twice during the week for shorter time periods.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: absolutely!  This class has truly challenged and enriched me in so many ways, where I found myself synthesizing thoughts and knowledge from so many different fields beyond architecture, be it philosophy, design, anthropology, biology, and sociology.
Yes! Great course for both architecture and non-architecture majors interested in biodegradable materials!
Yes. Mae-ling is fantastic, especially getting to know her outside of class.
Yes! Mae-Ling is a brilliant instructor and the course content is unique for the Yale undergraduate curriculum.
Yes! It took me out of my comfort zone, but it was one of the more interesting Yale classes that I have taken.
Definitely yes. You're learning about cutting-edge topics with massive potential impact. It is also super low workload and the professor is very, very chill.

extras.title: ARCH 337 01 - Field to Building, and Back
